data.annotated_text: What ' s worse than ransomware that scrambles all your files and demands money for the key to unlock them and get them back ? Well , <S0> WannaCry certainly added a new dimension to the ransomware danger </S0> , because <S1> it combined the data-scrambling process with self-spreading computer virus code </S1> . As a result , <S2> WannaCry could worm its way through your network automatically </S2> , potentially leaving you with hundreds or even thousands of scrambled computers in a single attack , even if only one user opened a booby-trapped attachment or downloaded a file from a poisoned website . The crooks behind the SamSam ransomware have also latched onto a rather different approach : instead of trying to reach thousands or tens of thousands of victims around the world with a hard-hitting spam campaign , and squeezing each of them for hundreds or thousands of dollars each , the SamSammers seem to attack one organisation at a time . Indeed , the SamSammers generally keep their hand hidden until they have broken into the network and figured out , using similar techniques to penetration testers , a list of computers they know they can encrypt all at the same time .

But <S1> clearing each computer took time and additional resources ' including the Colorado National Guard ' to investigate , contain and recover </S1> . <S4> We were able to recover from the SamSam attack </S2> relatively quickly </S4> due to our robust backup plan and our segmentation strategies , Brandi Simmons , a spokesperson for Colorado ' s Office of Information Technology , said in an email . <S5> We are still capturing costs associated with the incident </S5> , but our estimate is between $ 1M and $ 1.5M. What started with a core team of 25 IT employees , Simmons said , ballooned to 150 during the peak of the incident ' March 2-9 . She added that others included CDOT , the FBI , state emergency operations and private companies .

data.annotated_text: The city has spent the past two weeks restoring online services disrupted by ransomware that held encrypted data hostage . Soon after Atlanta City Auditor Amanda Noble logged onto her work computer the morning of March 22 , she knew something was wrong . <S1> The icons on her desktop looked different'in some cases replaced with black rectangles'and </S1> she noticed many of the files on her desktop had been renamed with weapologize or imsorry extensions . Noble called the city ' s chief information security officer to report the problem and left a message . Next , she called the help desk and was put on hold for a while . At that point , I realized that I wasn ' t the only one in the office with computer problems , Noble says . Those computer problems were part of <S0> a high-profile ransomware cyberattack on the City of Atlanta that has lasted nearly two weeks and has yet to be fully resolved </S0> . During that time the metropolis has struggled to recover encrypted data on employees ' computers and restore services on the municipal Web site .

While <S2> countries across Europe ' the United Kingdom , Ukraine , Spain and France , to name a few ' were hit hardest by the outbreak </S2> , <S3> the virus has now spread to the United States </S3> . Today , one of the largest drug makers in the U.S. , Merck , reported being infected by the malware , as did the multinational law firm DLA Piper , which counts more than 20 offices in the U.S. Heritage Valley Health Systems , a health care network that runs two hospitals in Western Pennsylvania , also confirmed in a statement to Recode on Tuesday that it was a victim of the same ransomware attack that has spread around the globe . <S4> At least one surgery had to be postponed because of the hack </S4> , according to a woman interviewed by Pittsburgh Action News 4 .

data.annotated_text: <S0> A malicious website initially set up to extort visitors to pay a cryptocurrency ransom has changed its course </S0> . Instead of demanding payment via Bitcoin , Ethereum , Bitcoin Cash or Litecoin in exchange for not leaking your password on the internet , <S1> the site now hijacks your computer ' s processing power to mine cryptocurrency in the background </S1> . Designed as a copy of the Have I Been Pwned attack , <S3> the site began by asking users to enter their emails to see if their password has been compromised </S3> . Unfortunately , if your password was breached , <S6> the site demanded a donation of $ 10 by cryptocurrency to not publish your password in plain text on the web </S6> . Up to 1.4 billion passwords may have been breached , but it ' s unclear how accurate that figure is . However , because <S2> it may be easier ' and safer ' to change your password than pay the ransom </S2> , as The Next Web noted , <S7> the site shifted its focus from demanding ransomware payments to taking over your PC ' s processing power to mine for cryptocurrency </S5> in <S8_unk> the background </S8_unk> .

data.annotated_text: IBM ' s latest X-Force Threat Intelligence Index report reveals that <S0> more than 2.9 billion records were leaked through publicly disclosed incidents in 2017 </S0> . While that sounds horribly bad , there ' s a bright side to this stormy disclosure : <S8> the number is 25 percent lower than the amount of records leaked in 2016 </S8> . Why ? Because <S9> hackers are shifting over to ransomware </S9> . <S5> They ' re becoming more focused on holding files hostage for money than on unleashing all that data to the dark markets </S5> . According to IBM , <S6> this shift to ransomware cost corporations more than $ 8 billion globally during 2017 </S6> , a number derived from <S7> downtime , ransom payments , and other impacts on day-to-day business </S7> . <S4> The global logistics and transportation industries alone lost millions of dollars in revenue during 2017 </S4> due to <S3> ransomware attacks </S3> . Ransomware is a type of malware that infiltrates a network and encrypts files on connected PCs . These files become unrecoverable , and <S2> require a key generated by the hacker to be released from </S1> captivity </S2> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> A flaw in certificate pinning exposed customers of a number of high-profile banks to man-in-the-middle attacks on both iOS and Android devices </S0> . A vulnerability in the mobile apps of major banks could have allowed attackers to steal customers ' credentials including usernames , passwords , and pin codes , according to researchers . <S1> The flaw was found in apps by HSBC , NatWest , Co-op , Santander , and Allied Irish bank </S1> . <S2> The banks in question have now all updated their apps to protect against the flaw </S2> . Uncovered by researchers in the Security and Privacy Group at the University of Birmingham , the vulnerability allows an attacker who is on the same network as the victim to perform a man-in-the-middle attack and steal information . The vulnerability lay in the certificate pinning technology , a security mechanism used to prevent impersonation attacks and use of fraudulent certificates by only accepting certificates signed by a single pinned CA root certificate .

data.annotated_text: <S0> The Git community has disclosed a security vulnerability affecting the clone and submodule commands that could enable remote code execution when vulnerable machines access malicious repositories </S0> . <S5> The vulnerability , which has been assigned CVE'2018'17456 by Mitre , has been fixed in Git 2.19.1 </S5> . To <S3> trigger the vulnerability </S3> , <S2> a malicious repository could forge a .gitmodules containing an URL starting with a dash </S2> . This would affect both git clone -- recurse-submodules and git submodule update -- recursive in that <S4> they would recursively pass the URL starting with a dash to a git clone or git submodule subprocess that would interpret the URL as a command option </S4> . This could lead to <S1> executing an arbitrary command on the local machine </S1> . This vulnerability is similar to CVE'2017'1000117 , which also enabled an option-injection attack by forging ssh URLs starting with a dash that would be interpreted as an option by the ssh subprocess executed by git . No exploits are known at the moment . We were also able to use the time to scan all repositories on GitHub for evidence of the attack being used in the wild .

The move has resulted in <S4> Google 's Project Zero once again calling Apple out for fixing iOS and macOS security flaws without documenting them in public security advisories </S4> . While it 's good news that <S2> Apple beat Project Zero 's 90-day deadline for patching or disclosing the bugs it finds </S2> , <S3> the group 's Ivan Fratric recently argued that <S1> the practice endangered users by not fully informing them why an update should be installed </S3> . This time the criticism comes from Project Zero 's Ian Beer , who 's been credited by Apple with finding dozens of serious security flaws in iOS and macOS over the years . Beer posted a blog about several vulnerabilities in iOS 7 he found in 2014 that share commonalities with several bugs he has found in iOS 11.4.1 , some of which he 's now released exploits for .

data.annotated_text: <S0> The US Postal Service says it ' s fixed a security weakness on usps.com that let anyone see the personal account info of its users , including usernames and street addresses </S0> . The open vulnerability was reportedly identified over a year ago by an independent researcher but <S6> USPS never patched it until this week </S6> , when Krebs on Security flagged the issue . <S3> The vulnerability included all 60 million user accounts on the website </S3> . It was caused by <S5> an authentication weakness in the site ' s application programming interface ( API ) that allowed anyone to access a USPS database offered to businesses and advertisers to track user data and packages </S5> . The API should have verified whether an account had permissions to read user data but USPS didn ' t have such controls in place . <S4> Users ' personal data including emails , phone numbers , mailing campaign data were all exposed to anyone who was logged into </S1> the </S2> site </S4> .

data.annotated_text: Update , <S0> Cisco will take a second crack at addressing a vulnerability in WebEx that can be exploited to execute malicious code on a vulnerable installation </S0> . <S1> Switchzilla has issued a new fix to address CVE-2018-15442 </S1> , a command injection bug in its video conference software that allows a local attacker to their elevate privileges , and then execute code by injecting commands through the software update component of the WebEx Meetings Client . The bug was traced back to <S4> the failure by Webex Meetings to properly check arguments passed via its update service commands </S4> . Thus <S5> a miscreant could run an update command with specially crafted arguments to ultimately execute code with system privileges </S5> . This means <S3> rogue logged-in users or malware on a Windows system could leverage WebEx to completely hijack the machine </S3> . <S2> Cisco had hoped to plug the vulnerability in October with a patch that was thought to have resolved the flaw </S2> . However , <S6> software-breakers at SecureAuth found that Switchzilla failed to account for DLL preloading </S6> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> For the second time in roughly a year , D-Link has failed to act on warnings from security researchers involving the company ' s routers </S0> . The latest incident arose after <S1> Silesian University of Technology researcher B?azej Adamczyk contacted D-Link last May about three vulnerabilities affecting eight router models </S1> . Following the warning , <S2> D-Link patched two of the affected routers , but did not initially reveal how it would proceed for the remaining six models </S2> . After further prompting from Adamczyk , D-Link revealed that the remaining six routers would not get a security patch because they were considered end-of-life models , <S3> leaving affected owners out in the cold </S3> . The D-Link models affected are the DWR-116 , DWR-140L , DWR-512 , DWR-640L , DWR-712 , DWR-912 , DWR-921 , and DWR-111 , six of which date from 2013 , with the DIR-640L first appearing in 2012 and the DWR-111 in 2014 , Naked Security reported . Though these are not current models in D-Link ' s portfolio , many of the listed models are still likely to be in use .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Microsoft and Google have been bitter rivals for at least a decade </S0> , and <S5> the pair have had several disagreements over security vulnerability disclosure in recent years </S5> . <S1> Google is stoking those disagreements again this week by disclosing a Microsoft Edge security flaw before a patch is available </S1> . <S7> Neowin spotted that <S6> Google disclosed the security flaw to Microsoft back in November </S7> , and <S2> the company provided 90 days for Microsoft to fix it before going public as it ' s rated medium in terms of severity </S2> . <S3> Google also provided Microsoft with an additional 14-day grace period to have a fix available for its monthly Patch Tuesday release in February </S3> , but Microsoft missed this goal because the fix is more complex than initially anticipated. It ' s not clear when Microsoft will have a fix available , and <S4> the Google engineer responsible for reporting the security flaw </S4> says because of the complexity of the fix Microsoft do not yet have a fixed date set as of yet. The public disclosure will likely anger Microsoft , once again .

data.annotated_text: Oracle released its latest Critical Patch Update on July 18 , <S1> fixing 334 vulnerabilities across the company 's product portfolio </S1> . <S3> The company rated 61 of the vulnerabilities as having critical impact </S3> . Among the products patched by Oracle are Oracle Database Server , Oracle Global Lifecycle Management , Oracle Fusion Middleware , Oracle E-Business Suite , Oracle PeopleSoft , Oracle Siebel CRM , Oracle Industry Applications , Oracle Java SE , Oracle Virtualization , Oracle MySQL and Oracle Sun Systems Products Suite . While there are issues of varying severity in the update , <S4> Oracle is blaming third-party components </S4> as being the cause of the majority of the critical issues </S2> . `` It is fair to note that <S0> bugs in third-party components make up a disproportionate amount of severe vulnerabilities in this Critical Patch Update </S0> , '' Eric Maurice , director of security assurance at Oracle , wrote in a blog post . `` 90 percent of the critical vulnerabilities addressed in this Critical Patch Update are for non-Oracle CVEs . '' Of the 334 issues fixed in the July Critical Patch Update , 37 percent were for third-party components included in Oracle product distributions .

data.annotated_text: <S0> CIsco has issued a critical patch of a patch for a Cisco Prime License Manager SQL fix </S0> . <S5> Cisco this week said it patched a critical patch for its Prime License Manager ( PLM ) software that would let attackers execute random SQL queries </S5> . <S10> The Cisco Prime License Manager offers enterprise-wide management of user-based licensing , including license fulfillment </S10> . <S8> Released in November , the first version of the Prime License Manager patch </S8> caused <S6> its own functional problems </S6> that <S1> Cisco was then forced to fix </S1> . That patch , called ciscocm.CSCvk30822_v1.0.k3.cop.sgn addressed the SQL vulnerability but caused <S3> backup , upgrade and restore problems </S3> , and should no longer be used Cisco said </S2> . <S7> Cisco wrote that customers who have previously installed the ciscocm.CSCvk30822_v1.0.k3.cop.sgn patch should upgrade to the ciscocm.CSCvk30822_v2.0.k3.cop.sgn patch to remediate the functional issues </S7> . <S4> Installing the v2.0 patch </S4> will first rollback the v1.0 patch and then install the v2.0 patch. As for the vulnerability that started this process , Cisco says it is due to <S9> a lack of proper validation of user-supplied input in SQL queries </S9> .

data.annotated_text: <S1> Tumblr has fixed a vulnerability </S0> that it says could have exposed private user data </S1> , according to an announcement by the microblogging and social networking site . The information that could have been viewed by unauthorized parties includes email addresses , hashed and salted passwords , locations , previously used email addresses , and last login IPs . <S3> The flaw resided in the Recommended Blogs feature in the desktop version of Tumblr </S3> . The widget shows logged-in users a list of blogs that may be of interest to them . If a blog appeared in the module , it was possible , using debugging software in a certain way , to view certain account information associated with the blog , said Tumblr . Discovered and reported through the platform ' s bug bounty program several weeks ago , <S2> the security vulnerability was resolved within 12 hours </S2> . <S4> The New York-based company also said that it couldn ' t determine which specific accounts were at risk </S4> , although its analysis is said to have shown that <S5> the bug was rarely present </S5> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Microsoft issued numerous bug fixes on its most recent Patch Tuesday </S0> , but according to the security firm 0patch , there were issues with one of the flaws for a critical vulnerability . The vulnerability in question , ( CVE-2018-8423 ) , is a memory corruption vulnerability that exists in the Jet Database Engine that , when exploited , allows for remote code execution . <S4> 0patch noticed that <S2> the patch Microsoft had issued was flawed </S4> as a result of <S3> studying the official patch of the Jet Database Engine and a micropatch that the security researchers had created for the same flaw </S3> . They explain this revelation as follows : As expected , <S5> the update brought a modified msrd3x40.dll binary </S5> : this is the binary with the vulnerability , which we had micropatched with 4 CPU instructions ( one of which was just for reporting purposes ) . <S6> The version of msrd3x40.dll changed from 4.0.9801.0 to 4.0.9801.5 </S6> and of course , its cryptographic hash also changed - which resulted in <S1> our micropatch for this issue no longer getting applied to msrd3x40.dll </S1> .

data.annotated_text: <S1> Cisco has released fixes for 34 flaws in its software </S0> , including 24 that affect its FXOS software for Firepower firewalls and NX-OS software for Nexus switches </S1> . <S3> Cisco 's June updates include fixes for five critical arbitrary code execution vulnerabilities affecting FXOS and NX-OS and 19 high-rated flaws affecting the software </S3> . Four of the critical flaws affect FXOS and NX-OS Cisco Fabric Services , while the fifth one affects the NX-API feature of NX-OS . All have a CVSS v3 score of 9.8 out of a maximum of 10 . <S5> Cisco Fabric Services facilitate distribution and synchronization of configuration data between Cisco devices on the same network </S5> . Some of the flaws allow an unauthenticated , remote attack to execute arbitrary code and one allows an attacker to do so as root . <S4> Multiple switches are vulnerable if they 've been configured to use Cisco Fabric Services , including its Nexus 2000 series through to Nexus 9000 series switches , as well as Cisco 's Firepower 4100 Series Next-Gen Firewalls and other hardware </S4> . <S2> The insufficient input validation may occur when FXOS and NX-OS process Cisco Fabric Services packets received during distribution and synchronization </S2> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Admins can now grab Cisco 's updates for 13 high-severity flaws affecting gear that uses its IOS and IOS XE networking software </S0> . <S4> All the bugs have been rated as having a high security impact </S4> because <S5> they could be used to gain elevated privileges or jam a device with denial-of-service ( DoS ) attacks </S5> . <S3> The company also has fixes available for 11 more flaws outlined in 10 advisories with a medium-severity rating , most of which also address issues in IOS and IOS XE , the Linux-based train of Cisco 's popular networking operating system </S3> . <S2> The updates for the 13 high-severity IOS and IOS XE flaws </S2> are part of Cisco 's scheduled twice-yearly patch bundle for this software targeted for September . <S1> The company reported this week that some IOS XE releases were among 88 Cisco products vulnerable to the DoS attack on Linux systems known as FragmentSmack </S1> . And earlier this month it plugged a critical hard-coded password bug in its video surveillance software . None of the flaws in the latest advisory is known to have been used in attacks and <S6> Cisco is n't aware of any public disclosures </S6> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> A severe WordPress vulnerability which has been left a year without being patched </S0> has the potential to <S3> disrupt countless websites running the CMS </S3> , researchers claim . At the BSides technical cybersecurity conference in Manchester on Thursday , Secarma researcher Sam Thomas said <S4> the bug permits attackers to exploit the WordPress PHP framework </S4> , resulting in <S6> a full system compromise </S1> . If the domain permits the upload of files , such as image formats </S6> , <S7> attackers can upload a crafted thumbnail file in order to trigger a file operation through the `` phar : // '' stream wrapper </S7> . In turn , <S5> the exploit triggers eXternal Entity ( XXE -- XML ) and Server Side Request Forgery ( SSRF ) flaws </S5> which cause <S2> unserialization in the platform 's code </S2> . While these flaws may only originally result in information disclosure and may be low risk , they can act as a pathway to a more serious remote code execution attack .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Mozilla has recently fixed multiple security flaws in its Thunderbird 60.3 email client </S0> . These vulnerabilities also include a critical security bug that allegedly affected Mozilla ' s Firefox and Firefox ESR browsers as well . <S4> Last week , <S1> Mozilla patched multiple security flaws altogether in its latest Thunderbird 60.3 including a critical security flaw </S4> . As explained in Mozilla ' s security advisory , <S3> numerous community members and developers at Mozilla discovered reported memory safety bugs </S2> that only affected Thunderbird email client , but also had impacted Firefox and Firefox ESR </S3> . Describing the bugs ( CVE-2018-12390 ) , Mozilla stated , Some of these bugs showed evidence of memory corruption and we presume that with enough effort that some of these could be exploited to run arbitrary code . Mozilla has fixed the bugs in Firefox 63 , Firefox ESR 60.3 , and Thunderbird 60.3 respectively . Apart from the critical memory safety bugs , Mozilla also released fixes for several other vulnerabilities affecting Thunderbird . These include three vulnerabilities with a high severity level , and low severity level memory safety bugs ( CVE-2018-12389 ) .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Cisco has released a new patch designed to fix <S6> a failed update </S3> which has not prevented the exploit of a severe Webex vulnerability </S6> . The original security flaw , CVE-2018-15442 , is present in the Cisco Webex Meetings Desktop App for Windows and is described as a bug which `` could allow an authenticated , local attacker to execute arbitrary commands as a privileged user . '' <S7> Cisco 's original security update was published in October </S7> in order to remedy the flaw , in which <S2> a lack of validation for user-supplied parameters in the app could be harnessed to exploit the bug </S2> . If an attacker is successful in utilizing the vulnerability , they can force the app to run arbitrary commands with user privileges . `` While <S4> the CVSS Attack Vector metric denotes the requirement for an attacker to have local access </S4> , <S5> administrators should be aware that in Active Directory deployments , the vulnerability could be exploited remotely by leveraging the operating system remote management tools </S5> , '' the company added . <S1> Software releases prior to 33.6.4 -- alongside Cisco Webex Productivity Tools Releases 32.6.0 and later prior to 33.0.6 -- are impacted on Windows systems </S1> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> A Google Project Zero researcher has published a macOS exploit </S0> to demonstrate that <S2> Apple is exposing its users to security risks </S2> by <S6> patching serious flaws in iOS </S6> but not revealing the fact </S4> until <S3> it fixes the same bugs in macOS a week later </S3> . This happened during Apple 's update for critical flaws in iOS 12 , tvOS 12 and Safari 12 on September 17 . A Wayback Machine snapshot of the original advisory does n't mention any of the bugs that Project Zero researcher Ivan Fratric had reported to Apple , and which were actually fixed . Then , a week later , after <S5> Apple patched the same bugs in macOS </S5> , <S1> the company updated its original advisory with details about the nine flaws that Fratric had reported , six of which affected Safari </S1> . The update fixed a Safari bug that allowed arbitrary code execution on macOS if a vulnerable version of Safari browsed to a website hosting an exploit for the bugs .

data.annotated_text: <S1> Cisco has resolved a set of critical vulnerabilities in Policy Suite </S0> which permit attackers to cause havoc in the software 's databases </S1> . This week , <S2> the tech giant released a security advisory detailing four vulnerabilities </S2> which could place enterprise users at risk of information leaks , account compromise , database tampering , and more . The first vulnerability , CVE-2018-0374 , has earned a CVSS base score of 9.8 . Described as an unauthenticated bypass bug , <S4> the security flaw `` could allow an unauthenticated , remote attacker to connect directly to the Policy Builder database </S4> , '' according to Cisco . <S3> The bug </S3> has been caused by a simple lack of authentication and as there is no requirement for identity verification , Policy Builder databases can be accessed and tampering with without limitation . Cisco Policy Suite releases prior to 18.2.0 are affected . The second vulnerability , CVE-2018-0375 , is a default password error . The CVSS 9.8 bug is present in the Cluster Manager of Cisco Policy Suite and could allow an unauthenticated , remote attacker to log in to a vulnerable system using a root account .

According to Krebs , <S0> the flaw </S0> was caused by <S2> an authentication weakness in the application programming interface ( API ) on usps.com that supported the USPS 'Informed Visibility ' program , which offers business customers `` near real-time tracking data '' about mail campaigns and packages </S2> . The bug let anyone who was logged in to usps.com to see account details for others users , including email address , username , user ID , account number , street address , phone number , authorized users , mailing campaign data and more .

data.annotated_text: As thousands of freshmen move into their dorms for the first time , there are plenty of thoughts rushing through their minds : their first time away from home , what cringey nickname they 're gon na try to make a thing , if there are any parties before orientation kicks off . One thing that probably is n't on their minds is whether they 're going to get hacked . But that 's all Carnegie Mellon University 's IT department thinks about . Back-to-school season means <S2> hordes of vulnerable computers arriving on campus </S2> . The beginning of the semester is the most vulnerable time for a campus network , and <S1> every year , with new students coming in , schools have to make sure everything runs smoothly </S1> . Carnegie Mellon 's network gets hit with 1,000 attacks a minute -- and that 's on a normal day . Cybersecurity is an increasingly important aspect of our everyday lives , with technology playing a massive role in nearly everything we do . Universities have been vulnerable to attacks in the past , with <S0> cybercriminals stealing student and faculty databases and hackers vandalizing university websites </S0> .

Action Fraud is warning that criminals are sending out emails pretending to be from TV Licensing . <S3> The watchdog says it has already received over 200 reports about the phishing scam </S3> . <S4> The email lures you in by saying you are owed a refund on your TV Licence payments </S4> . But , it ' s a con and all the senders are really after is your bank details . What does the email say ? So far all the emails have been the same . They say : This is an official notification from TV Licensing ! We would like to notify you that , after the last annual calculation we have determined that you are eligible to receive a TV Licensing refund of 85.07 GBP . Due to invalid account details records , <S1> we were unable to credit your account </S1> .

data.annotated_text: It seems the old warning 'you get what you pay for ' can just as easily be applied to items purchased on underground forums and the dark web as it can to anything you buy elsewhere , because unbeknown to those experimenting with free phishing kits , they 're secretly being phished themselves . <S0> An analysis of over one thousand phishing kits designed to allow wannabe cybercriminals to build phishing emails and websites </S0> found that , in a significant proportion of cases , the trainee phishers are being compromised , with their stolen data being secretly sent to the kit authors . With phishing simple to carry out but potentially very financially rewarding -- some of the highest profile cyber-attacks of recent years began with a phishing email -- it 's no wonder that newbie hackers want in . But their lack of skill is coming back to bite some of these aspiring cybercriminals , who might find that all their ill-gotten gains are also transferred to the original author of the kit .

Criminals pose as the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency in a bid to extort motorists of their cash by requesting this bank details . <S1> These crooks usually try to achieve this by threatening a monetary punishment of some sort or in other cases by stating that the driver is entitled to a refund </S1> . The problem for some motorists could fall for the fraudulent messages especially as they often look fairly professional and can even contain the logo of the DVLA Motorists Jason Price , however , was not fooled by the latest attempt by fraudsters trying to get him to hand over his details . Mr Price tweeted a link to the email that he received from the criminal pretending to be the DVLA .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Email is great for keeping in touch with friends and family and quickly conversing with colleagues </S0> but it ' s not without its pitfalls . Scammers approach people via email to encourage them to hand over private or sensitive information about themselves or the company they work for . The most prevalent threats we see targeting consumers today are phishing attacks predominantly via email , where <S2> scammers try to trick people into sharing private information or access to money </S2> , Jessica Brookes , director of EMEA consumer at McAfee , told the Press Association . The first thing you should know about phishing is that it almost always involves a form of ' social engineering ' , in which <S1> the scammer tries to manipulate you into trusting them for fraudulent purposes </S1> , often by pretending to be a legitimate person or business .

Those other emails suggesting the recipients have a $ 64 tax refund waiting at the IRS or that the IRS needs information about insurance policies'also fake . data.annotated_text: Phishing takes place when a fraudster tricks an individual into sharing sensitive information ( account numbers , Social Security numbers , login credentials , etc . ) by way of <S1> fraudulent emails , texts , or counterfeit websites </S1> . <S2> Phishing can also enable a scammer to gain access to a computer or network </S2> so that <S0> they can install malware , such as ransomware , on a victim 's computer </S0> . <S3> Phishers are able to achieve this by spoofing the familiar , trusted logos of established , legitimate companies </S3> . Or , they may pose as a friend or family member and are often successful in completely deluding their targets . In carrying out attacks , Dark Caracal uses trojanized WhatsApp and Facebook apps to try to lure users into clicking malicious links and downloading Android malware , called Pallas , which can collect vast amounts of data . Dark Caracal targets include governments , military organizations , utilities , financial institutions , manufacturing companies and defense contractors .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Authorities on Wednesday charged two Iranian citizens for <S2> the ransomware cyber attack that hobbled the city of Atlanta ' s computer network in March </S2> , and <S5> the federal indictment outlines the pair ' s massive nationwide scheme to breach computer networks of local governments , health care systems and other public entities </S5> . The defendants , Faramarz Shahi Savandi , 34 , and Mohammad Mehdi Shah Mansouri , 27 , are alleged to have developed the SamSam ransomware , malicious software that encrypts data until the infected organizations paid ransom . All told , <S3> the pair inflicted harm on more than 200 victims across the country </S3> and collected roughly $ 6 million in ransom over a three year period dating back to 2015 . Their scheme caused <S1> over $ 30 million in losses to various entities </S1> , according to federal authorities . <S4> The hack to city of Atlanta computers in March crippled city business for days </S4> . One internal report that surfaced in August estimated the damage to the city could cost up to $ 17 million .

data.annotated_text: LabCorp , one of the largest clinical labs in the U.S. , said <S0> the Samsam ransomware attack that forced their systems offline was contained quickly </S0> and did n't result in a data breach . However , in the brief time between detection and mitigation , <S2> the ransomware was able to encrypt thousands of systems and several hundred production servers </S2> . <S6> The wider public first learned about the LabCorp incident </S6> on Monday , when <S5> the company disclosed it via an 8-K filing with the SEC </S5> . Since then , as recovery efforts continue , the company said they 're at about 90-percent operational capacity . According to sources familiar with the investigation , <S7> the Samsam attack at LabCorp started at midnight on July 13 </S7> . This is when <S3> the Samsam group used brute force against RDP and deployed ransomware by the same name to the LabCorp network </S3> . At 6:00 p.m. on Saturday , July 14 , the first computer was encrypted . <S4> The LabCorp SOC ( Security Operation Center ) immediately took action after that first system was encrypted </S4> , <S1> alerting IR teams and severing various links and connections </S1> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> MONTREAL'On Sept 10 , municipal employees in a region between Montreal and Quebec City arrived at work to discover a threatening message on their computers notifying them they were locked out of all their files </S0> . In order to regain access to its data , <S1> the regional municipality of Mekinac was told to deposit eight units of the digital currency Bitcoin into a bank account ' roughly equivalent to $ 65,000 </S1> . Mekinac ' s IT department eventually negotiated the cyber extortionists down and paid $ 30,000 in Bitcoin , but not before the region ' s servers were disabled for about two weeks . The attack highlights the inability of many small municipalities to adequately protect their data , but also <S2> the lack of guidance on cybersecurity provided to them by the Quebec government </S2> , according to Prof. Jose Fernandez , a malware expert at Montreal ' s Polytechnique engineering school . Quebec is an embarrassment , Fernandez said in an interview , adding that he has tried without success to contact government representatives to alert them to <S3> the problem </S3> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Officials at a medical practice in Blue Springs say they are taking steps to strengthen privacy protections </S0> after <S1> a ransomware attack affected nearly 45,000 patients </S1> . Blue Springs Family Care discovered in May that hackers had installed malware and ransomware encryption programs on its computer system , giving them full access to patient records . Ransomware is a kind of malware that locks up a computer . <S3> The attackers typically demand a ransom , often in Bitcoin or other cryptocurrencies </S3> , as a condition of unlocking the computer and allowing access to the system . Melanie Peterson , Blue Springs Family Care ' s privacy officer , says the medical practice did not pay a ransom . Rather , it was able to use backups to regain computer access . In a letter to patients , Blue Springs Family Care said it had no evidence patients ' information had been used by unauthorized individuals . But <S2> it said it had taken steps to strengthen its defenses against similar attacks in the future </S2> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> The bug was found in the core infrastructure of Apache Struts 2 </S0> . <S1> The Apache Software Foundation has patched a critical security vulnerability which affects all versions of Apache Struts 2 </S1> . Uncovered by researchers from cybersecurity firm Semmle , <S3> the security flaw </S3> is caused by <S2> the insufficient validation of untrusted user data in the core Struts framework </S2> . When <S5> Apache Struts uses results with no namespace and in the same time , upper actions have no wild namespace </S5> . The same opportunity for exploit exists when the URL tag is in use and there is no value or action set . As <S6> the bug , CVE-2018-11776 , has been discovered in the Struts core </S6> , the team says there are multiple attack vectors threat actors could use to exploit the vulnerability . If <S7> the alwaysSelectFullNamespace flag is set to true in the Struts configuration </S7> , which is automatically the case when the Struts Convention plugin is in use , or if a user 's Struts configuration file contains a tag that does not specify the optional namespace attribute or specifies a wildcard namespace . <S4> Man Yue Mo from the Semmle Security Research Team first reported the flaw </S4> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Security biz Qualys has revealed three vulnerabilities in a component of systemd , a system and service manager used in most major Linux distributions </S0> . <S2> Patches for the three flaws CVE-2018-16864 , CVE-2018-16865 , and CVE-2018-16866 should appear in distro repos </S1> soon </S2> as a result of <S5> coordinated disclosure </S5> . However , <S8> Linux distributions such as Debian remain vulnerable at the moment , depending on the version you have installed </S8> . `` <S3> They 're aware of the issues and <S4> they 're releasing patches </S4> , '' said Jimmy Graham , director of product management at Qualys , in a phone interview with The Register . `` I do n't believe Red Hat has released one but it should be coming shortly . '' The bugs were found in systemd-journald , a part of systemd that handles the collection and storage of log data . The first two CVEs refer to memory corruption flaws while the third involves an out of bounds error that can leak data . CVE-2018-16864 can be exploited by malware running on a Linux box , or a malicious logged-in user , to <S6> crash and potentially hijack the systemd-journald system service </S6> , <S7> elevating access from user to root </S7> .

data.annotated_text: <S1> A privilege escalation flaw in McAfee 's True Key software remains open to exploitation </S0> despite <S2> multiple attempts to patch it </S2> . This according to researchers with security shop Exodus Intel , who claim that <S4> CVE-2018-6661 was not fully addressed with either of the two patches McAfee released for it </S4> . The flaw is <S3> an elevation of privilege issue in McAfee 's TrueKey password manager </S3> . An exploit can be carried out on a guest account by side-loading a specially-crafted DLL into True Key that would then <S6> allow for commands and code to be executed with system-level privileges </S6> . McAfee 's summary of the flaw , published on March 30 , lists it as a 'high ' severity issue that was patched in version 4.20.110 - which was released in April . Exodus says that the April release did n't fully fix the bug , however . The researchers explain that <S5> McAfee 's patch only addresses one of the libraries ( SDKLibAdapter ) that would allow the attack to take place </S5> , with another DLL ( NLog logging library ) being left vulnerable to the same side-loading tactic .

You can see the specifics of his ( very complicated ) procedure in the video below . Apple also says it has fixed a bug that caused <S0> the new iPhones to stop charging when their screens turned off </S0> . This was n't an issue our review unit had , but it was noted throughout multiple forums and message boards . <S4> The company has fixed a number of smaller bugs </S4> as well . A bug that caused the phone to automatically join 2.4-GHz networks rather than 5 GHz networks , a bug that sometimes caused Bluetooth to become unavailable , and <S2> a bug that blocked subtitles from appearing in some video apps are no longer </S2> .

The fixed update can be downloaded from Microsoft 's download center and not the Microsoft Update Catalog . data.annotated_text: <S1> A fraud chief at Britain ' s biggest bank has admitted scam texts are now so sophisticated </S1> even he sometimes can not tell if they are genuine </S0> . Paul Davis , retail fraud director at Lloyds Banking Group , told Money Mail criminals can mimic the exact format of messages which appear as though they are sent from a bank ' s number using a technique called ' spoofing ' . With fake banking texts now so difficult to spot , <S3> Mr Davis said customers should be taught how to respond to them </S3> to avoid being lured into a scam </S2> . He added : ' It ' s the new don ' t talk to strangers . 'We teach children how to cross the road and we also need to teach everyone how to be aware of and stay safe from scams . It ' s the new basic life safety advice we all need to know. ' Mr Davis said the key to avoiding falling for scams was to treat all messages with caution . ' It ' s about what you say when you reply , ' he said .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Cybercriminals are finding it more difficult to maintain the malicious URLs and deceptive domains used for phishing attacks for more than a few hours </S0> because <S1> action is being taken to remove them from the internet much more quickly </S1> . That does n't mean that <S3> phishing -- one of the most common means of performing cyber-attacks -- is any less dangerous </S3> , but <S5> a faster approach to dealing with the issue is starting to hinder attacks </S5> . <S4> Deceptive domain names look like those of authentic services </S4> , so that <S2> somebody who clicks on a malicious link may not realise they are n't visiting the real website of the organisation being spoofed </S2> . One of the most common agencies to be imitated by cyber-attackers around the world is that of government tax collectors . The idea behind such attacks is that people will be tricked into believing they are owed money by emails claiming to be from the taxman . However , no payment ever comes , and if a victim falls for such an attack , they 're only going to lose money when their bank details are stolen , and they can even have their personal information compromised .

data.annotated_text: <S1> A phishing campaign is targeting customers of every major UK bank </S1> , with <S3> cybercriminals posing as customer support staff on Twitter </S3> in an attempt to steal users ' online banking credentials . Easy to carry out but difficult to defend against , <S5> phishing is an increasingly popular weapon of choice for hackers </S5> . That 's because , with an authentic-looking fake website , <S6> they can just sit back and scoop up data as victims unwittingly hand over their usernames and passwords </S6> . <S4> Phishing often relies on cybercriminals sending tailored emails to potential victims </S4> in an effort to lure them into giving up credentials or installing malware . However , cybersecurity researchers at Proofpoint have uncovered an Angler phishing campaign which , rather than being tailored to specific users , takes advantage of how they can often be careless on social media -- specifically Twitter . In this instance , <S2> cybercriminals monitor Twitter for users approaching genuine support accounts for banks </S2> , and <S0> attempt to hijack the conversation with a fake support page </S0> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Phishing is one of the most devious scams for filching your personal information </S0> , but experts say it is possible to avoid them if you know what you 're looking for . At its essence , phishing is the act of pretending to be someone or something you trust in order to trick you into entering sensitive data like your user name and password . The goal -- of course -- is to take your money . Some of the most common phishing scams are bogus emails purportedly from trustworthy institutions like the U.S.Internal Revenue Service or major banks . The more sophisticated scams are crafted to look very much like a legitimate message from a site you do business with . Many popular phishing scams purport to be from shipping companies , e-commerce companies , social networking websites , financial institutions , tax-preparation companies and some of the world ' s most notable companies , said Norton by Symantec senior security response manager Satnam Narang via email .

spans.text: Phishing is one of the most devious scams for filching your personal information

data.annotated_text: <S0> Staff are still falling for phishing scams </S0> , with social media friend requests and emails pretending to come from the HR department among the ones most likely to fool workers into handing over usernames and passwords . <S1> Phishing scams aim to trick staff into handing over data -- normally usernames and passwords -- by posing as legitimate email </S1> . It 's a technique used by the lowliest criminals as part of ransomware campaigns , right up to state-backed hackers because it continues to be such an effective method . In a review of 100 simulated attack campaigns for 48 of its clients , accounting for almost a million individual users , security company MWR Infosecurity found that sending a bogus friend request was the best way to get someone to click on a link -- even when the email was being sent to a work email address . Almost a quarter of users clicked the link to be taken through to a fake login screen , with more than half going on to provide a username and password , and four out of five then going on to download a file .

data.annotated_text: Noticed more emails and texts lately claiming to be from your bank and not just yours ? You ' re not the only one . Action Fraud , the UK police ' s dedicated fraud tracking team , has revealed a significant increase in reports about phishing attacks connected to TSB ' s massive IT outage have been reported . A total of 176 complaints have been received , or around ten a day since April 30 . <S4> There has been an uptick in phishing attempts across the piece </S4> , says an Action Fraud spokesperson . <S5> TSB ' s banking meltdown </S5> , caused by <S1> a botched IT upgrade </S0> , still has not been remedied nearly four weeks on </S1> . And <S2> the crisis has become paydirt for scammers and hackers , who have waded into a confusing , chaotic situation and are making out with thousands of pounds worth of savings from people ' s accounts </S2> . And it ' s not just TSB - the number of phishing texts claiming to be from other banks such as Barclays and NatWest also seems to be on <S3> the rise </S3> .

data.annotated_text: In the wake of <S5> Hurricane Florence disaster </S5> , <S6> ONWASA , a water utility company has been specifically targeted by cyber criminals </S6> . ONWASA provides water and sewer service to all of Onslow County except Jacksonville residents . According to a press release , <S7> ONWASA 's internal computer system , including servers and personal computers , have been subjected to a sophisticated ransomware </S4> attack </S7> . <S1> The attack has left the utility with limited computer capabilities </S1> . CEO Jeffrey Hudson said customer information was not compromised in the attack . However , <S0> many other databases must be recreated in their entirety </S0> . <S3> ONWASA is working with the FBI , the Department of Homeland Security , the state of North Carolina and several technology security companies </S3> . They are also receiving help from N.C . Senator Harry Brown and N.C . Senator Thom Tillis . Hudson said he believes the attack was a targeted one because <S2> the hackers chose a local government that has recently been ransacked by a natural disaster </S2> . The hackers struck at 3 a.m. on Saturday -- a time Hudson says was their most vulnerable .

data.annotated_text: <S1> A Vermont business 's computer system was attacked by hackers </S0> and held for ransom </S1> . It may sound like a movie plot but ransomware attacks like these are on the rise . According to their 2017 Internet Crime report , <S3> last year the FBI received 1,783 complaints identified as ransomware </S3> . The adjusted losses from the attacks was over $ 2.3 million . An example of a ransomware attack is <S4> software that downloads to your computer , encrypts your data and then demands money to get it back </S4> . It 's technological extortion , essentially . And that 's what happened to Wendell 's Furniture in Colchester at the end of last month . `` Our servers crashed and <S2> when our IT guy came to take care of the problem </S2> , I asked him how the patient was doing and he just got kind of an ashen look on his face and he just shook his head and I knew we were in trouble , '' said Ryan Farrell , the vice president of Wendell 's Furniture . Farrell says in their nearly 20 years of business , they 've never had this type of cybersecurity attack .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Six million of Verizon 's US customers had their personal and account information exposed , including PIN numbers </S0> . <S2> Verizon Communications suffered a major data leak </S2> due to <S6> a misconfigured cloud server that exposed data on 6 million of its customers </S6> . <S3> The leak </S3> was the result of <S5> its third-party provider NICE Systems incorrectly configuring Verizon 's cloud-based file repository housed in an Amazon Web Services S3 bucket on NICE 's cloud server </S5> , according to UpGuard , which issued a report on the breach today . <S1> Verizon customer names , addresses , account information , including account personal identification numbers ( PINs ) , were compromised </S1> . <S4> UpGuard in its data estimated that up to 14 million customer records were exposed </S4> , but Verizon stated that data on 6 million of its users was affected . In one file alone , there were 6,000 PINs that were publicly exposed , according to Dan O'Sullivan , a cyber resilience analyst for UpGuard . What 's unique about this leak is that it was not just personal data that was publicly exposed but also PINs , according to O'Sullivan .

data.annotated_text: Researchers have discovered some serious security flaws threatening Linux . These vulnerabilities exist in Linux systemd component . According to the researchers , <S1> the vulnerabilities pose a risk to all systemd-based Linux distros </S1> . Allegedly , <S2> researchers at Qualys have disclosed some bugs targeting the Linux systemd component </S2> . <S3> Systemd provides the core building blocks for Linux and handles major processes after booting </S3> . As revealed , three vulnerabilities have targeted the systemd-journald , which is responsible for data collection and log storage . The vulnerabilities let an attacker gain root privileges on the target device . The researchers state that these vulnerabilities threaten all Linux distros based on systemd except a few . As stated in their report , To the best of our knowledge , all systemd-based Linux distributions are vulnerable , but <S0> SUSE Linux Enterprise 15 , openSUSE Leap 15.0 , and Fedora 28 and 29 are not exploitable </S0> because their user space is compiled with GCC ' s -fstack-clash-protection. The three bugs include two different memory corruption flaws ( CVE-2018-16864 and CVE-2018-16865 ) , and an out-of-bounds flaw ( CVE-2018-16866 ) .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Enigmail and GPG Tools have been patched for EFAIL </S0> . For more up-to-date information , please see EFF 's Surveillance Self-Defense guides . <S2> Don ' t panic ! But you should stop using PGP for encrypted email and switch to a different secure communications method for now </S2> . <S1> A group of researchers released a paper today that describes a new class of serious vulnerabilities in PGP ( including GPG ) , the most popular email encryption standard </S1> . The new paper includes a proof-of-concept exploit that can allow an attacker to use the victim ' s own email client to decrypt previously acquired messages and return the decrypted content to the attacker without alerting the victim . The proof of concept is only one implementation of this new type of attack , and variants may follow in the coming days .

data.annotated_text: <S0> The Bitcoin Core team yesterday released a patch for a DDoS vulnerability that could prove fatal to the Bitcoin network </S0> . <S2> The patch note urged miners to shut down their older versions urgently and replace them with the new version , Bitcoin Core 0.16.3 </S2> . The announcement , first reported on Hacked , revealed that all the recent Bitcoin Core versions could be vulnerable to Distributed Denial-of-Service attack . An attack of such kind typically involves <S4> multiple compromised systems to flood a single system ( or network ) similar to zombies encircling an uninfected person and disabling his movements </S4> . <S8> DDoS perpetrators could attack a Bitcoin network </S8> by either <S7> flooding the block with duplicate transactions </S7> , thus <S5> jamming the transaction confirmation of other people </S5> , or by <S1> flooding the nodes on Bitcoin ' s peer-to-peer network </S1> , thus <S6> over-utilizing the bandwidth through malicious transaction relays </S6> . <S3> The recent DDoS vulnerability , termed as CVE-2018-17144 , tried to attempt the latter flooding full node operators with traffic </S3> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> A security bug in Systemd can be exploited over the network </S0> to , at best , potentially crash a vulnerable Linux machine , or , at worst , execute malicious code on the box . <S2> The flaw </S2> therefore <S1> puts Systemd-powered Linux computers specifically those using systemd-networkd at risk of remote hijacking </S1> : <S6> maliciously crafted DHCPv6 packets can try to exploit the programming cockup </S5> and arbitrarily change parts of memory in vulnerable systems </S6> , leading to <S4> potential code execution </S4> . This code could install malware , spyware , and other nasties , if successful . The vulnerability which was made public this week sits within the written-from-scratch DHCPv6 client of the open-source Systemd management suite , which is built into various flavors of Linux . This client is activated automatically if IPv6 support is enabled , and relevant packets arrive for processing . Thus , a rogue DHCPv6 server on a network , or in an ISP , could emit specially crafted router advertisement messages that wake up these clients , <S3> exploit the bug </S3> , and possibly hijack or crash vulnerable Systemd-powered Linux machines .

data.annotated_text: Overall , <S0> the chip giant patched five vulnerabilities across an array of its products </S0> . <S1> Intel on Tuesday patched three high-severity vulnerabilities that could allow the escalation of privileges across an array of products </S1> . Overall , the chip giant fixed five bugs three rated high-severity , and two medium-severity . The most concerning of these bugs is an escalation-of-privilege glitch in Intel ' s PROset/Wireless Wi-Fi software , which is its wireless connection management tool . The vulnerability , CVE-2018-12177 , has a high CVSS score of 7.8 , according to Intel ' s update . <S2> Intel is releasing software updates to mitigate this potential vulnerability </S2> , it said , urging users to update to version 20.90.0.7 or later of the software . The vulnerability , reported by Thomas Hibbert of Insomnia Security , stems from improper directory permissions plaguing the software ' s ZeroConfig service in versions before 20.90.0.7 . The issue could allow an authorized user to potentially enable escalation of privilege via local access . The other high-severity bug exists in the company ' s System Support Utility for Windows , which offers support for Intel-packed Windows device users .

data.annotated_text: The US Attorney 's Office for the District of Northern Georgia announced Wednesday that a federal grand jury had returned indictments against two Iranian nationals charged with executing the March 2018 ransomware attack that paralyzed Atlanta city government services for over a week . Faramarz Shahi Savandi and Mohammed Mehdi Shah Mansouri are accused of using the Samsam ransomware to encrypt files on 3,789 City of Atlanta computers , including servers and workstations , in an attempt to extort Bitcoin from Atlanta officials . Details leaked by City of Atlanta employees during the ransomware attack , including screenshots of the demand message posted on city computers , indicated that Samsam-based malware was used . A Samsam variant was used in a number of ransomware attacks on hospitals in 2016 , with <S0> attackers using vulnerable Java Web services to gain entry in several cases </S0> . In more recent attacks , including one on the health industry companies Hancock Health and Allscripts , other methods were used to gain access , including Remote Desktop Protocol hacks that gave the attackers direct access to Windows systems on the victims ' networks . The Atlanta attack was not a targeted state-sponsored attack .

Byung BJay Pak , the U.S. attorney in Atlanta , said in a news release that <S1> the Atlanta indictment was sought in coordination with the earlier indictment </S1> and seeks to ensure that those responsible for the attacks face justice here as well. The Atlanta indictment accuses the two men of launching a ransomware attack against Atlanta that encrypted vital city computer systems . <S5> The attack significantly disrupted city operations </S5> and caused <S6> millions of dollars in losses </S6> , prosecutors said .

'' <S3> Attackers can run code as System user Following <S4> a successful attack of a vulnerable Microsoft Exchange Server installations </S4> , <S1> potential attackers would be able to take advantage of System user permissions </S1> . An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could run arbitrary code in the context of the System user . An attacker could then install programs ; view , change , or delete data ; or create new accounts . data.annotated_text: <S0> Yesterday , on Microsoft ' s Patch Tuesday the company released its monthly security patches that <S1> fixed 62 security flaws </S1> . These fixes also included a fix for a zero-day vulnerability that was under active exploitation before these patches were made available . <S3> Microsoft also announced the re-release of its Windows 10 version 1809 and Windows Server 2019 </S3> . <S2> Microsoft credited Kaspersky Lab researchers for discovering this zero-day , which is also known as CVE-2018-8589 and impacts the Windows Win32k component </S2> . A Kaspersky spokesperson told ZDNet , they discovered the zero-day being exploited by multiple cyber-espionage groups ( APTs ) . The zero-day had been used to elevate privileges on 32-bit Windows 7 versions . This is the second Windows elevation of privilege zero-day patched by Microsoft discovered by Kaspersky researchers . Last month , Microsoft patched CVE-2018-8453 , another zero-day that had been used by a state-backed cyber-espionage group known as FruityArmor . However , in this month ' s Patch Tuesday , Microsoft has not patched a zero-day that is affecting the Windows Data Sharing Service ( dssvc.dll ) . This zero-day was disclosed on Twitter at the end of October .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Microsoft rolled out 60 patches for its Patch Tuesday release </S0> , <S1> impacting 19 critical flaws and 39 important flaws </S1> . Microsoft has rolled out its August Patch Tuesday fixes , addressing 19 critical vulnerabilities , including fixes for two zero-day vulnerabilities that are under active attack . Overall , <S2> the company patched a total of 60 flaws </S2> , spanning Microsoft Windows , Edge , Internet Explorer ( IE ) , Office , .NET Framework , ChakraCore , Exchange Server , Microsoft SQL Server and Visual Studio . Of those , 19 were critical , 39 were rated important , one was moderate and one was rated low in severity . The patch release includes two exploited flaws , CVE-2018-8373 and CVE-2018-8414 , which were previously disclosed by researchers . The first zero-day , CVE-2018-8373 , could result in remote code-execution ( RCE ) and grants the same privileges as a logged-in user , including administrative rights . The vulnerability exists in IE 9 , 10 and 11 , impacting all Windows operating systems from Server 2008 to Windows 10 .

data.annotated_text: Most CISOs like a challenge . Matthew Maglieri faced more than a challenge when he agreed to become the chief information security officer for Ruby Life Inc. , parent of the Toronto-based Ashley Madison and other dating sites which in 2015 saw hackers release records of some 36 million members , plus application code and corporate email . Even Maglieri says the company suffered a tremendous loss of consumer trust , and users relied on discretion using the service , and that <S0> discretion was violated. When he tried recruiting security staff this year a number balked when hearing who their employer would be </S0> . In fact , he admitted Wednesday at the monthly meeting of the Toronto Area Security Klatch ( TASK ) , a group of infosec pros and students , that a headhunter he consulted flatly told him to decline the offer . Absolutely not , your personal brand is at stake , he recalled being told . And that ' s why he said yes . I thought about it ' If I don ' t do this there isn ' t going to be anybody fighting for the users , he said .

Only emails and hashed password were exposed </S3> . The archive contained only emails and hashed passwords , but not payment card details or DNA test result . MyHeritage says it uses third-party payment processors for financial operations , meaning <S6> payment data was never stored on its systems </S6> , while <S1> DNA test results were saved on separate servers from the one that managed user accounts </S1> . Based on the creation dates of some accounts , <S2> the breach appears to have taken place on October 26 , 2017 </S2> . It is unclear if the breach is the result of a <S0> hacker attack </S0> or because of <S5> a malicious employee selling the company 's data </S5> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Criminals are attempting to trick consumers into handing over passwords and credit card details </S0> by taking advantage of the flood of emails being sent out ahead of new European privacy legislation . <S3> The European Union 's new General Data Protection Regulation ( GDPR ) come into force on 25 May </S3> and <S4> the policy is designed to give consumers more control over their online data </S4> . As a result , in the run-up to it , <S2> organisations are sending out messages to customers to gain their consent for remaining on their mailing lists </S2> . With so many of these messages being sent out , it was perhaps only a matter of time before opportunistic cybercriminals looked to take advantage of the deluge of messages about GDPR and privacy policies arriving in people 's inboxes . A GDPR-related phishing scam uncovered by researchers at cyber security firm Redscan is doing just this in an effort to steal data with emails claiming to be from Airbnb . The attackers appear to be targeting business email addresses , which suggests <S1> the messages are sent to emails scraped from the web </S1> .

According to a company blog post last week , <S1> the pre-installed malware was detected in 38 Android devices , belonging to a large telecommunications company and a multinational technology company </S1> . <S2> The malicious apps were not part of the official ROM supplied by the vendor </S2> , and were added somewhere along the supply chain , the company said . <S4> The malware added to the devices ' ROM could not be removed by the users </S4> , therefore , <S3> the devices had to be re-flashed </S3> . The research team at Check Point found that one of the pre-installed malwares was Slocker , a mobile ransomware , that uses the Advanced Encryption Standard ( AES ) encryption algorithm to encrypt all files on the device and demand ransom in return for their decryption key . The most notable rough adnet which targeted the devices is the Loki Malware .

data.annotated_text: If there ' s one thing that can be counted on to happen every year around tax season ' besides the ongoing tax preparation service commercials ' it ' s fraud . Whether it ' s selling W2 forms online or sending malicious emails that look like they are from the IRS , <S0> cybercriminals tend to keep themselves busy this time of year </S0> . Rick Holland , VP of strategy at Digital Shadows , joined this week ' s Hacker Tracker to highlight how cybercriminals are utilizing the dark web to support their tax fraud campaigns . Earlier this year , the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration reported that there was a reduction in the number of fraudulent tax returns identified between 2013 and 2015 . On the other hand , around that same time the IRS released data showing that phishing and malware incidents in the 2016 tax season increased by 400 percent . Noting that the number of identified fraudulent returns was not indicative of the overall levels of tax fraud occurring , <S2> Digital Shadows set out to reconcile two very different perspectives </S1> on the same problem </S2> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> An unsecured backup drive has exposed thousands of US Air Force documents , including highly sensitive personnel files on senior and high-ranking officers </S0> . <S4> Security researchers found that the gigabytes of files were accessible to anyone </S4> because <S3> the internet-connected backup drive was not password protected </S3> . <S1> The files , reviewed by ZDNet , contained a range of personal information , such as names and addresses , ranks , and Social Security numbers of more than 4,000 officers </S1> . Another file lists the security clearance levels of hundreds of other officers , some of whom possess `` top secret '' clearance , and access to sensitive compartmented information and codeword-level clearance . Phone numbers and contact information of staff and their spouses , as well as other sensitive and private personal information , were found in several other spreadsheets . The drive is understood to belong to a lieutenant colonel , whose name we are not publishing . ZDNet reached out to the officer by email but did not hear back . <S2> The data was secured last week after a notification by MacKeeper security researcher Bob Diachenko </S2> .

data.annotated_text: <S1> The Advocate sought the ransom demand amount </S1> with a public records request of the Licking County Commissioners </S0> . Licking County Prosecutor Bill Hayes provided The Advocate the information Monday . <S5> A computer virus discovered Jan 31 </S5> caused <S4> Licking County government to shut down about 1,000 computers and its phone systems </S4> to <S3> prevent the virus from spreading , protect data and preserve evidence </S3> . The FBI and Bureau of Criminal Investigation were notified . County officials chose not to pay the ransom , and <S2> recovered data from its backups </S2> . By Feb 16 , most of the county system was back in service . Licking County Commissioner Tim Bubb said the price per bitcoin was about $ 1,100 when the computers were hacked , making the demand about $ 30,000 . As of 4 p.m. Monday , the value of one bitcoin was $ 1,235 . The computer hack cost the county more than $ 50,000 , Bubb said , which includes insurance and overtime , but he does not regret refusing to pay the demand . `` I 'm just kind of hard-nosed about that , '' Bubb said .

data.annotated_text: In total , ESET security researcher Lukas Stefanko discovered 13 apps that appear to have been written by a Turkish developer . While seven of the 13 apps obviously focused on Turkish-speaking users , the rest targeted users from across the world . Stefanko says he reported all 13 apps to Google 's security team , who removed them from the Play Store last week . The modus operandi of all these apps was the same . <S2> The app would then collect the user 's login details , send them to a remote server , and show a login error </S2> . <S1> The error would appear every time the user tried to authenticate </S1> , and after a certain number of login attempts , <S0> the error would change </S0> , and ask the user to visit the official Instagram site instead and authorize the app from there . When the user visited the Instagram homepage , he would see a notification from Instagram letting him know that someone has accessed his account . From this point on , if victims do n't change their passwords , the crook would use the victim 's Instagram account to like images or follow other accounts .

data.annotated_text: <S0> About 33 million records belonging to Dun & Bradstreet have been leaked </S0> , <S1> placing a large portion of the US corporate population at risk </S1> . According to independent researcher Troy Hunt , <S2> the database is about 52 gigabytes in size and contains just under 33.7 million unique email addresses and other contact information from employees of thousands of large enterprises and government entities </S2> . While details are unfolding , the leak is thought to be from a database <S3> D & B acquired from NetProspex in 2015 </S3> . The file is a list rental file that D & B offers marketers for use for their own email campaigns . It ' s believed that one of these marketing firms is the source of the leak itself having been compromised in some way . `` <S4> We 've carefully evaluated the information that was shared with us and it is of a type and in a format that we deliver to customers every day </S4> , D & B said in a media statement .

data.annotated_text: <S1> Ransomware has largely been an opportunistic , rather than a targeted , form of cybercrime </S0> with the goal of infecting as many users as possible </S1> . That model has worked so effectively that <S5> extortion is now ubiquitous when it comes to cybercrime </S5> ' so much so that <S4> even fake attacks are proving to be successful </S4> . As I wrote earlier this month , <S3> the surge of extortion attacks impacting organizations </S3> has led to <S2> a number of fake extortion threats </S2> , including empty ransomware demands where actors contact organizations , lie about the organization ' s data being encrypted , and ask for money to remove the non-existent threat . Cybercriminals like to follow the path of least resistance , and an attack doesn ' t get much easier than simply pretending to have done something malicious . However , <S7> attacks over the past year have proven that infecting organizations with ransomware </S7> can result in much higher payouts . <S9> The more disruptive the attack </S9> , <S8> the more money some organizations are willing to pay to make the problem go </S8> away </S6> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> While combing through WikiLeaks ' Vault 7 data dump </S0> , <S3> Cisco has unearthed a critical vulnerability affecting 300+ of its switches and one gateway that could be exploited to take over the devices </S3> . <S7> The flaw is present in the Cisco Cluster Management Protocol ( CMP ) processing code in Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE Software </S7> . <S5> The vulnerability </S5> is due to the combination of two factors : <S6> the failure to restrict the use of CMP-specific Telnet options only to internal , local communications between cluster members and instead accept and process such options over any Telnet connection to an affected device </S6> , and <S4> the incorrect processing of malformed CMP-specific Telnet options </S4> , Cisco explained . An exploit could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code and obtain full control of the device or cause <S2> a reload of the affected device </S2> . The extensive and complete list of affected devices is provided in the security advisory . <S1> Cisco says that they are not aware of any public announcements or active malicious use of the vulnerability </S1> , and that they will provide free software updates to address it ( they don ' t say when ) .

data.annotated_text: Google Nest ' s Dropcam , Dropcam Pro , Nest Cam Outdoor and Nest Cam Indoor security cameras can be easily disabled by an attacker that ' s in their Bluetooth range , a security researcher has found . <S5> The vulnerabilities are present in the latest firmware version running on the devices ( v5.2.1 ) </S5> . They were discovered by researcher Jason Doyle last fall , and their existence responsibly disclosed to Google , but have still not been patched . <S6> The first two flaws can be triggered </S6> and lead to <S0> a buffer overflow condition </S0> if the attacker sends to the camera a too-long Wi-Fi SSID parameter or a long encrypted password parameter , respectively . That ' s easy to do as <S1> Bluetooth is never disabled after the initial setup of the cameras </S1> , and <S2> attackers ( e.g . burglars ) can usually come close enough to them to perform the attack </S2> . <S4> Triggering one of these flaws </S4> will make <S3> the devices crash and reboot </S3> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> The recent political furor over state sponsored hacking took an ugly and dangerous turn </S0> , on <S3> the morning of December 30th when a tiny Vermont electric utility reported that Grizzly Steppe the spear-fishing process used to access DNC emails had been found on one of their systems </S3> . <S2> Vermont Governor , Peter Shumlin issued a statement accusing Vladimir Putin of attempting to hack Vermont ' s electrical grid </S2> , and many others follow suit . And there appears to be a good chance that <S1> the malicious code found on a Burlington Electric laptop is evidence of a state sponsored cyberattack </S1> . Following the initial news cycle , some pundits dismissed the finding as a non-story . It ' s true , <S4> the laptop was not connected to the power grid systems </S4> , and there is no proof yet that the Russians were involved . It ' s also true that the Russian built Grizzly Steppe hacking code is widely available on the dark internet , and anyone could have put it on that laptop .

data.annotated_text: <S0> Some medical devices , smartphones and internet of things gadgets contain certain types of sensors that are vulnerable to potential hacking using sound waves </S0> , says cybersecurity researcher Kevin Fu . `` This is now a risk that all manufacturers should be aware of , and in their hazard analysis , it has to be a part of their cybersecurity risk management , '' says Fu , explaining findings of a recent research study conducted by the University of Michigan and the University of South Carolina . The microelectromechanical systems - or MEMS accelerometers - that the research team found to contain these vulnerabilities - are sensors used in various devices to measure acceleration or velocity , and then report those readings to a microprocessor . `` What we looked at was the ability to trick these sensors into delivering false readings to the microprocessor by using sound waves , '' he says in an interview with Information Security Media Group . `` What medical devices contain these sensors is still an open question . The main hazard of this sound wave vulnerability is the threat to the integrity and availability of the sensor , he explains .

data.annotated_text: <S0> A week ago the Moodle developers released updates for the still supported branches of the platform : 3.2.2 , 3.1.5 , 3.0.9 and 2.7.19 </S0> . The release notes mentioned that `` <S2> a number of security related issues were resolved </S2> , '' but did n't provide any additional details about their nature or impact . <S5> The severity of the flaws became apparent Monday </S5> , when security researcher Netanel Rubin , who found the vulnerabilities , published a detailed blog post about them . They do n't seem too critical on their own , but when combined , they allow attackers to create hidden administrative accounts and execute malicious PHP code on the underlying server . The exploit takes advantage of some false assumptions made by the developers , which Rubin described as a logic flaw , an Object Injection , a double SQL injection , and an overly permissive administrative dashboard . The logic issue stems from <S1> the reimplementation of a certain function without taking into account decisions made by the original function 's developers </S1> . According to the researcher , it is the result of <S3> `` <S4> having too much code , too many developers and lacking documentation </S4> .

data.annotated_text: <S0> A severe vulnerability has been disclosed in libpurple , the library used in the development of a number of popular instant messaging clients , including Pidgin and Adium for the macOS platform </S0> . Adium 1.5.10.2 is vulnerable and can be exploited to run arbitrary code remotely . A researcher who goes by the handle Erythronium submitted a post on March 15 to the Adium developers mailing list about the issue . While <S1> there ' s been some discussion of a fix for CVE-2017-2640 , no Adium advisory or patches have been released </S1> . In the meantime , Erythronium told Threatpost that libpurple and Adium should no longer be used . Unless the [ Adium ] dev team comes out with an advisory about this issue , a serious apology , a completely solid story about how they plan to handle future vulnerabilities in their codebase and its dependencies , and a way for people to reproduce their builds without depending on a creepy binary blob of libpurple , people should simply stop using it , the researcher said .
